Mais shap, Ã  certains Ã©gards, prÃ©sente des limitesÂ : stabilitÃ© des contributions de shapley, prise en compte des corrÃ©lations, causalitÃ©s entre variables explicatives,Â â€¦

Plusieurs maniÃ¨res de calculer les valeurs deÂ Shapley

Le but de lâ€™Ã©tude menÃ©e conjointement par Quantmetry et la MAIF consiste Ã  Ã©valuer lâ€™impact des mÃ©thodes de calcul des valeurs de Shapley dans la qualitÃ© des explications. En effet, comme nous allons le rappeler, les valeurs de Shapley utilisÃ©es en explicabilitÃ© sont dÃ©finies non seulement Ã  partir de la â€œformuleâ€ prÃ©dictive x â†’ f(x), mais impliquent aussi la loi de probabilitÃ© des variables explicatives Xâ‚,Â Xâ‚‚,â€¦,Xp

https://medium.com/media/6d7e371aca9dddfc240d1b9fcad14fbb/href

Malheureusement, aucune de ces lois nâ€™est connue en pratique, et elles doivent Ãªtre estimÃ©es Ã  partir des donnÃ©es Ã  disposition. Câ€™est pour cela quâ€™un autre estimateur, plus gÃ©nÃ©ral et plus prÃ©cis, a Ã©tÃ© proposÃ© et implÃ©mentÃ© dans la librairie ACV (Active Coalition of Variables). Les comparaisons sur des modÃ¨les standards simples montrentÂ :

Les valeurs de Shapley servent Ã  attribuer un score dâ€™importance locale aux diffÃ©rentes variables, qui permet ensuite de les classer pour identifier le groupe de variables les plus importantes. Nous nous posons alors deux questionsÂ :

In fine, il sâ€™agit bien sÃ»r de dÃ©terminer quelle librairie fournit les analyses les plus cohÃ©rentes avec les expertises mÃ©tiers.

Un autre point que nous cherchons Ã  quantifier est lâ€™impact de la mauvaise gestion par SHAP des variables catÃ©goriellesÂ : en effet, la sommation des valeurs de Shapley de â€œvariables catÃ©gorielles One-Hot-Encodedâ€ est mathÃ©matiquement fausse. De la mÃªme maniÃ¨re que dans les autres cas, nous cherchons Ã  dÃ©terminer et Ã  valider avec de vraies explications mÃ©tiers, si des estimations â€œsparsesâ€ peuvent capturer lâ€™essentiel des rÃ©sultats.

Ainsi cette Ã©tude contient 3 phases distinctes qui vont permettre de donner des recommandations sur lâ€™une ou lâ€™autre librairie pour le calcul des valeurs de Shapley. Nous souhaitons notamment pouvoir caractÃ©riser les individus pour lesquels ces Ã©carts sont trÃ¨s importants car nous partons du principe quâ€™une IA de confiance doit pouvoir expliquer tous les individus de la mÃªme faÃ§on, de maniÃ¨reÂ fiable.

Pour les groupes de variables, la valeur est un dictionnaire de lâ€™ensemble des valeurs des variables duÂ groupe.

Sur ces exemples ci-dessus, les principales variables contributrices, sont des variables groupÃ©es, ce qui permet de rÃ©sumer plus facilement la prÃ©diction.

Avec ces nouvelles fonctionnalitÃ©s, nous espÃ©rons que Shapash puisse encore plus faciliter la comprÃ©hension dâ€™un modÃ¨le de machine learning.

Pour plus de dÃ©tails, nous vous invitons Ã  dÃ©couvrir le tutoriel sur le GitHubÂ Shapash.

La version FranÃ§aise de cet article est disponible ici.

Today we open Thoth, our Java library which offers a toolkit to implement event sourcing in your Java application.

Power your Java Apps with EventÂ Sourcing

Rather than maintaining an up-to-date application state, event sourcing focuses on what happened by storingÂ events.

This approach provides by-design audit log for the application.

It is also very well suited for event-driven architecturesÂ : events can be published asÂ is.

It plays well with CQRSÂ : building and maintaining read projections is done by consuming events.

Thoth guaranties that:

  • Events will be written in the database before being published in Kafka (to preventÂ failure)
  • Publication in Kafka will be reattempted until itÂ succeeds

It provides capabilities of defining two types of projectionsÂ :

  • â€œReal timeâ€ projections, that are updated in the same transaction as theÂ events
  • â€œEventually consistentâ€ projections, updated asynchronously by consuming Kafka

More information is available hereÂ : https://github.com/maif/thoth

You can also find demos hereÂ : https://github.com/MAIF/thoth/tree/master/demo

The other good news is Thoth comes with 3 other Java libraries which you may use with Thoth or independantlyÂ :

  • jooq asyncÂ : some glue between Vertx, Vavr andÂ Jooq
  • functional jsonÂ : a functional way to parse JSON usingÂ Jackson
  • functional validationÂ : a functional way to validateÂ beans

Jooq Async

Jooq Async allows you to use Jooq, Vertx Postgresql client and Vavr together. With this lib, you can build queries with the power of Jooq and run it on a small thread pool usingÂ Vertx.

More info hereÂ : https://github.com/MAIF/jooq-async

Functional Json

Functional Json helps you to manipulate JSON in a functional way.

It provides flowless helpers to write / read Jackson node, and elegant error handling.

More info hereÂ : https://github.com/MAIF/functional-json

Functional Validation

Functional Validation allows you to define atomic validation and compose them. At the end, you will have a successful validation or all the errors that have been collected.

You may also use Bean Validation JavaEE specification (JSR 303) and combine it with manual validation.

More info hereÂ : https://github.com/MAIF/functional-validation

Event sourcing powers a lots of our application. We hope Thoth will fit your needs and that you will enjoy itÂ !

text: Shapash: MAIF releases a new solution for a more transparent AI
description:
ShapashÂ : MAIF releases a new open source solution for a more transparent AI

MAIF, a french mutual insurance company (est. 1934), has been contributing to open-source for a few years. We released two solutions, Izanami and Otoroshi which are components of our micro-services platform. Since 2019, we also share our work in the field of artificial intelligence, our first release was Melusine, a tool for french langage email processing.

We are now releasing Shapash, a solution which aims to make AI algorithms more transparent and understandableÂ . Thus, it contributes to the ethical use ofÂ data.

Elements ofÂ context

In France, a lot of people are suspicious with AI. This suspicion is increased by Big Data which provides more data which can be used to train AI algorithms.

This comes with several risksÂ : misusage of private data, discriminatory biasesÂ â€¦ AI may also turn into unethical surveillance systems.

Within the European Union, public authorities are aware of these risks. They deal with these issues both at a European level with the GDPR and at a French level e.g. with the CNIL (French data protection agency).

Why we have made ShapashÂ ?

At MAIF, as an insurer, weâ€™ve been using data for a long time, to offer personalized advice to our customers as well as to control insurance risks. Because of our history, as a committed mutual insurance company and because we believe that companies should be responsible for their use of data, we are particularly involved in ethical usage ofÂ data.

We want our AI algorithms to be transparent because we believe it is essential to build and maintain trust inÂ AI.

We have also been studying for a few years how Data science models can be more intelligible and understandable. This is a growing field of study, and several relevant open-source contributions have already been published about it. However, they mainly target data practitioners and specialists.

With Shapash, MAIF data scientists wanted to share a solution for everyone, no matter their data background.

At MAIF, we use Shapash toÂ :

  • Help data experts and non-experts to communicate better
  • Make it easier and faster for MAIFâ€™s data scientists to understand how models they developÂ work.

We believe that Shapash had to be open-sourced.

We want to share a solution for all, no matter their data background.

What is ShapashÂ ?

Shapash a Python library that helps to make Machine Learning models more transparent and understood by everyone!

Concretely, it is an overlay to other intelligibility libraries (Shap, Lime)Â that:

  • Displays understandable results with easy-to-read and simple wording and visualization, adapted to everyone.
  • Displays an interface that helps to explore different features of a model and offers navigation between global and local explicability. This interface is particularly useful to animate workshops and answer questions on how ML modelsÂ work.
  • Summarizes local explicability to make it useful in an operational context. This summary is adaptable to different use cases and can be exported.
  • Is open! Shapash is used for Regression, Classification, and fits a multitude of Machine Learning libraries, feature encoding (inverse encoding), usable with contributions calculated by Lime, Shap,Â â€¦

Shapash can be used for all kinds of use casesÂ : health, business, marketing,Â â€¦

Please visit Shapashâ€™s GitHubÂ : you will there find more exhaustive documentation of the libraryâ€™s features as well as a demo of the Web App Shapash Monitor for a quick test! And do not hesitate to give us a star on GitHub if you like theÂ project!

Shapash: MAIF releases a new solution for a more transparent AI was originally published in OSS by MAIF on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Daikoku 1.0.0 is outÂ !!

A new MAIFâ€™s open source application is out. Like Batman has Robin, Otoroshi hasÂ Daikoku.

Daikoku is a developer portal for Otoroshi, written in scala and developed by the MAIF OSSÂ team.

text: Eurybia: MAIF releases a new open-source solution for quality IA models in production
description:
MAIF, a French mutual insurance company (est. 1934), has been contributing to open source for a few years. Since 2019, we share our work in the field of artificial intelligence, our first release was Melusine, for french langage email processing and our second was Shapash, to make machine learning interpretable and understandable by everyone.

We are now releasing Eurybia, a python library to ensure quality of machine learning model in production by detecting model drift. Eurybia also addresses challenges of industrialisation and maintainability of IA over time. Thus, it contributes for a better model monitoring, model auditing and more generally AI governance.

Elements ofÂ context

More and more machine learning models are being deployed into production environments. A key step for deployment is to secure the data that will be used for the prediction model. This is crucial, notably when training and production data sourcesÂ differ.

While most models have been built from historical data and are static, data are usually dynamic, meaning that they change over time and so do the prediction capabilities. To have a controlled use of AI, it is important to detect these changes to determine if they are problematic, track performance over time, and consider re-training the model if necessary.

Why have we madeÂ Eurybia?

At MAIF, as an insurer, weâ€™ve been using data for a long time, notably to simultaneously offer the best personalized advice to our customers and control insurance risks. Because of our history, as a committed mutual insurance company and because we believe that companies should be responsible for their use of data, we are particularly involved in AI governance.

The visualization of the life cycle of a machine learning model can ease the understanding of Eurybia importance. During their life, ML models go through the following phases: Model learning, Model deployment, Model monitoring.

To ensure that models perform in production as well as they did in training, it is important to verify that data are consistent and that features distributions areÂ similar.

We want to closely monitor our models in production, notably to detect as early as possible when models are likely to provide less suitable recommendations.

At MAIF, we use EurybiaÂ to:

  • Secure model deployment by detecting any inherent dataÂ problems
  • Help data analysts, data engineers and data scientists to collaborate for data validation before deploying a model into a production environment
  • Make it easier and faster for MAIFâ€™s data scientists to analyze dataÂ drift
  • Know whether it is necessary to re-train theÂ model
  • Save drift monitoring reports for drift monitoring, for consultation following an e-mail alert or another specificÂ need

What isÂ Eurybia?

Eurybia is a Python library which aims to help detecting drift and validate data before putting a model in production (named deployedÂ model).

Underneath, youâ€™ll see a short description of elements which are referred to in thisÂ article.

  • Data ValidationÂ : Validate that data used for production prediction are similar to training data or test data before deployment.
  • Data driftÂ : Evolution of the production data over time compared to training or test data before deployment.
  • Model driftÂ : Model performancesâ€™ evolution over time due to change in the target feature statistical properties (Concept drift), or due to change in data (DataÂ drift).

For technical definitions, we recommend to read the bibliography.

For Data Validation and Data Drift, Eurybia works mainly with a binary classification model (named datadrift classifier) that tries to predict whether a sample belongs to the training/baseline dataset or to the production/current dataset.

The explainability of this datadrift classifier provides higher scores to features that are important for drift. When combined with the initial deployed model features importances, this explainability reationalizes further analysis.

Eurybia thus allows its users toÂ :

  • Get a quick overview of features that changed the most to prioritize study ofÂ drift
  • Put into perspective the evolution of features with their importance for the deployed model. To study in priority drift on features with the most influence on theÂ model
  • Display each feature and its distribution
  • Display the difference between the predicted probabilities distributions respectively based on the baseline dataset and the production dataset
  • Have a performance metric for data drift and track it overÂ time

Eurybia also has additional features that allow toÂ :

  • Analyze data consistency by checking if features are the same between baseline and production dataset, as well as features modalities
  • Detect model drift by displaying model performance over time (a section we would like to develop in future Eurybia releases)
  • Save a dynamic report that allows collaboration between colleagues, drift analysis, and for auditÂ purposes

Eurybia can be used for all kinds of use cases and domainsÂ : health, business, marketing,Â â€¦

Please visit Eurybiaâ€™s GitHubÂ : there, you will find more exhaustive documentation of the libraryâ€™s features as well as a demo of the dynamic report for a quick test! Please do not hesitate to give us a star on GitHub if you like theÂ project!

Maif open source several libraries and not only data science libraries, you can visit themÂ here.

Further readings

We have quickly introduced the notion of drift. If you wish to learn more about drift, I recommend the following resourcesÂ :

  • Drift classification and retraining: https://towardsdatascience.com/model-drift-in-machine-learning-models-8f7e7413b563
  • Concept drift characterization: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1511.03816.pdf
  • Mathematical view for different types of driftsÂ : https://medium.com/data-from-the-trenches/a-primer-on-data-drift-18789ef252a6
  • Data drift detection: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2012.09258.pdf
